Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to solve basic differential equations, do Laplace and Fourier transforms.
None

How to solve first, second, and higher order ordinary linear differential equations as well as some partial differential equations using such methods as undetermined coefficients, Laplace transforms, integrating factor, variation of parameters, and exact equations.

I learned the basics of solving ordinary differential equations -- exact equations, guessing the form of solutions, the method of undetermined coefficients, variation of parameters, Laplace transforms -- and a bit about partial differential equations, such as separation of variables, heat transfer, and wave equations.
I learned how to solve various differential equations.
I learned several methods for solving differential equations.
How to solve ordinary differential equations and partial differential equations.
This is a required course for most engineering majors. It will give a solid introduction to solving ordinary differential equations, and a very brief introduction to partial differential equations.
Different methods of solving ordinary and partial differential equations.
I gained knowledge on the methods of solving ordinary and partial differential equations with some real life applications.
I learned a lot about differential equations and some applications.
ODEs but not really PDEs
I learned the foundations of how to solve ordinary differential equations (the unit of partial differential equations was too short and rushed in my opinion).
How to learn from Khan Academy and Paul's Online Notes
How to solve ordinary and partial differential equations
I learned that you can skip lecture if you judge the professor to be incompetent.

The course focuses primarily on how to set up and solve higher order differential equations through various methods such a variation of parameters and Laplace transforms. Partial derivatives are more so tossed in the end.
Only a brief overview of solving ordinary and partial differential equations.
Learned how to solve a variety of different types of differential equations.
I now know how to solve first order linear/nonlinear, second order liner, and higher order linear differential equations using various methods such as undetermined coefficients and Laplace equations.
I can solve a good number of differential equations!

I developed knowledge on how to solve ordinary and partial equations. However, all of the information and skills I gained from this course did not come from the class or the Professor at all. Rather everything I learned came from youtube and Khan Academy or occasionally TA office hours. All the math I learned was self taught since lectures only confused me further and all the material was conveyed in the most confusing manner.
Aside from learning differential equations concepts from the textbook, nothing.
I felt like I learned very comprehensive methods about how to handle diffeq problems, but learned no applications for these problems.
I learned an overview of differential equations, as well as a little introductory partial diffeq information at the end.
I learned how to solve differential equations using different methods.

I learned how to solve first order, second order, and higher order linear ordinary differential equations, some nonlinear first order ones, as well a some partial differential equations. I learned laplace transforms, fourier series, as well as how to solve boundary value problems.
Learned how to solve various differential equations using multiple methods.
Critical thinking from difficult math problems
Insight into differential equations
absolutely useless course
I learned how to solve some differential equations in this class.
I learned how to solve differential equations
You learn how to solve Ordinary Differential Equations using several different methods and some Partial Differential Equations.
I learned how to evaluate ordinary and partial differential equations, and apply methods such as Lagrangians.

Really, no strength. At all. Besides the fact that the tests had to be easy in order to compensate for the terrible teaching. Thank you TAs.


Weaknesses- The professor. Enough said.

Strengths:
-good TAs
-Midterms reflect course material very well
-reasonable workload

Weaknesses:
-confusing lectures
-lack of coherency between lecture and problem sets
-professor consistently referred to prerequisites for course that were not prerequisites for the course
-had to rely on TAs to learn material and not professor/lecture

The material that this course covers is fair and doesn't move too fast. Lots of help is offered, we are allowed to drop three problem sets, and the material isn't too difficult. I really enjoyed the structure of this course. Any weaknesses would have to be professor specific -- Professor Cao frequently got confused in class or had to go back on her previous examples to fix things, which was a little confusing. If she could be more focused on her examples and teaching, that would alleviate a lot of student confusion.
The course was very easy the first two portions of the semester and impossible the last portion.
The lectures were completely useless and should be spend doing example problems instead.

This course was a lot of material that was presented cohesively. Its strength was that solving differential equations is vital for engineers, but it weakness was that the class was not taught in a way that helped students succeed.

Strengths: Tests were fair and the TA's were very helpful
Weaknesses: class was not helpful and the final was too difficult for there to not be a curve, especially since it's worth 40% of the overall grade.

The course is very poorly taught. Professor Cao is definitely the courses major weakness. Her lectures were hard to follow, generated several confused questions in class, and in trying to answer those questions she often prompted even more. Often she would run late and only just introduce topics covered on that week's pset. I had to do most of my learning by just reading the text book, and she did a horrible job preparing the class for the partial differential equations on the final.

The only positive thing I have to say for this course was that the material was fairly interesting and I liked how it built up over the course of the semester.  As for the class, lecture was not helpful, and I often found myself confused with the material.  A more engaging and clear lecture would benefit students taking this course.
I think that the course had a nice overview on how to solve various differential equations. I wish there was more time/practice available for partial differential equations.
This course set up is good. It moved at a reasonable pace, however, we did run out of time at the end and the last chapter felt a little squished.
omg i didn't learn anything when i went to lecture but I made some great friends and that's all that matters in life.
Lecture was boring, but TA review sessions were very helpful in going over the material. The homework and exams were straight forward.
I do not know if this class has any strengths.

Strengths -- the course content is manageable for the most part in terms of problem sets and midterms; the TAs were amazing in their review sessions every week.
Weaknesses -- the final is definitely DIFFICULT compared to the midterms and often times you need to teach the material to yourself.

Strengths: The TA was really cute?

Weaknesses: There was no incentive to come to lecture for the entire year, the problem sets and midterms were easy, and then the final was impossible.

I thought  the course was well taught & the psets were hard, but helpful for learning the material. The midterms were not  very difficult &  truly  tested  the material  were did  in the  psets but then  the final was SO difficult.

The first two midterms were pretty representative of the homework and what was taught in the class. Final was very difficult for most people in the class and was representative of 40% of the semester grade. Two questions on the final (hardest ones) were worth 50% of its points.  Should change the point distribution of the final to be more representative of the class. Especially since it's not typically curved.
Professor is nice but very bad at teaching.

I think either the final should be made more comparable to the midterms, or the midterms to the final. I felt the midterms tested basic conceptual understanding of the concepts learned while the final asked for higher level applications.

The lectures themselves were almost exactly the same as the textbook, which is why much of the class stopped coming to lecture. The further problem remained in the fact that the textbook was poorly organized to facilitate learning. There was very little explanation of why we were using any given method or what the goal of each lecture was. In many cases, we simply jumped into an example problem without knowing what we were trying to do. While Professor Cao did a very very good job of responding to questions, she was simply unaware of students as she ran through the example problems which was not useful in engaging students.

There are no strengths to this course, except maybe the optional TA office hours offered on Tuesday and Wednesdays from 7-9pm where we could work on our Psets and receive guidance from the TAs. Other than that, this course only had weaknesses. The information was taught extremely fast in the most complicated manner. I would have to self teach myself everything and found youtube to be a MUCH better explainer than Hui ever was. Her accent also makes it difficult to understand, in additon to her hand writing. I often found myself in class completely lost, having NO idea what was going on... literally no idea. The information is conveyed so poorly- this class was awful.

There were no strengths of this course, aside from the fact that you do end up teaching yourself the material, and it satisfies a major requirement.

It had many, many weaknesses. Above all, it was taught even more poorly than I even thought was possible. The lectures were disorganized and error-laden, the class notes were messy and undecipherable, and the content was not properly relayed from the textbook. This was easily evident in that, in a class of around 80 people, fewer than 20 would show up to each lecture because even purely reading the textbook was more effective than going to class.

The most important weakness was in how poorly the class was set up for grading. Before the final exam, there was essentially no grade distribution. The mean on every problem set was above a 95 and the mean on both midterm exams was around 90% (with the mode on each exam being at or near 100%). Objectively, the midterms and problem sets' grading was far too easy. Then, the final exam was in an entirely different ballpark with difficulty. The exam was longer and more difficult, with an average in the mid-60%s. This exam was an odd wakeup call, shoved unceremoniously at students at the start of finals period with no prior warning (not to mention, zero practice questions or practice exam posted anywhere). So, essentially the entire distribution was based on this final exam, worth 40% of the overall grade. Honestly, it is hard to imagine a worse class at Yale or anywhere else. I am disappointed that such a class would be "taught" at an institution that supposedly prides itself on world-class and unparalleled teaching and learning.

This class is basically like a high school class in that you don't have to listen in class, the homework is basic, and the tests are easy. The TAs and teacher are not good at teaching, but definitely are trying. The final is impossibly hard and does not reflect any other material in the class.
This is mostly a very good course, with fair midterms and psets. However, the final was beyond a fair difficulty level (the average was 65) and the professor's lectures were not very clear.
The professor was a bit unclear with her teaching, but the problem sets were very helpful.

This course was poorly taught and overall was a very weak course. The lectures were hectic, too fast to follow, and dulled us all out of our minds. The beauty of differential equations was completely lost under a jumble of notation and mathematical tricks leaving us lacking in conceptual understanding but knowing how to manipulate symbols. The course was extremely easy to do well in up until the final. So many people had 100s at that point or close to. Then the final came out of no where and was incredibly hard compared to the rest of the course which was very unfair as many of us thought we were prepared. And then there was no opportunity to learn from our mistakes because the course had ended.

Lectures were often hard to followTA lectures during review sessions and working on psets was how I actually learned the material. The final being worth 40% with no curve but ten times more difficulty than the two midterms made 0 sense.

The problems we were given strongly facilitated learning of the topics. The problems on the final were far harder than homework problems however. Weaknesses were the teaching - I learned nothing from the style of teaching. We needed to do more problems as a class, and more difficult ones.
I thought it was not taught very clearly in lecture and that the lecture notes were difficult to follow. The TAs of the course were excellent.

The major weakness of this course was the disparity between the difficulty of the midterms and final exam. The averages on the midterms were in the mid 90s, but the average on the final was a 64%. And nothing was curved accordingly. This seems kind of ridiculous that the tests were so vastly different in difficulty. There should be more clarity as to what is expected on the exams, especially the final. 

The psets in this class were fine and good practice of the material. The office hours with the TAs were the true gems and helped many students succeed.
The strengths of this course are the Teaching Fellows and their review sessions. The weaknesses are the lack of engagement and at times confusing teaching style.

Professor Hui Cao could have done a much better job in engaging her students and explaining the material. The course would have been very engaging if the differential equations were explained in context in terms of applying them in real-life situations, but all Professor Cao did was copy her handwritten notes on a tablet that projected to the screen, while explaining each line. It would have been much more helpful if she explained better or explained some physics/engineering concepts in context (after all, it is ENAS). It may be partly due to her accent/language barrier as well.
No. Don't take it if you don't know how to solve differential equations already. You will regret it.
Not in a million years. Terrible all around, Prof. didn't know how to teach and didn't seem to care. TAs did all the work and we're a lot better teachers, put them in charge.

I would not recommend this course to another student. It teaches you the basics of things but I mostly learned on my own or through TAs. Most people don't show up to lecture because they realized it didn't help, but I went and was always confused. The workload is okay but I recommend a course that is more rewarding academically and better taught.

I would recommend this course. It gave me a foundation in differential equations that I feel fairly confident in, and that I have already started applying to some of my other classes, such as upper level physics. Additionally, the class really isn't too difficult -- the mode on both of our midterms was 100%, and the medians were in the 90s for both as well. You get to drop your three lowest problem set grades, which is really generous. Because of this, the class isn't curved, but it works out because of how easy exams are/generous the problem set grading is. You have a problem set every week, which covers exactly what you're going over in class, and there are two 2-hour study halls offered every week where the TAs will help you work through literally every homework problem. The material also isn't that difficult, and if you are an astrophysics or physics major looking for a class in differential equations, this is much better than Physics 301 from what I've heard.

I would not recommend this course. It was very boring and not lessons in class made no sense. We were told up front that we would not learn why equations work because there wasn't enough time for that so instead, we were just told equations and had to memorize them without understanding why they work. I pretty much taught myself everything with the textbook because classes weren't very insightful.
I would not recommend this course unless you absolutely have to take it. The teaching was simply bad and I really did not get much out of the course.
I would recommend this class to a student only if it was one of their requirements.

It's a requirement for most engineering majors, so many who take this don't have a choice. If you want to take it, I think it can be a fun, rewarding course, but try not to take it with Professor Cao.
I would not recommend this course to anyone.  It was by far the worst class I have ever taken.  Despite going to lecture, I had to self-learn all of the material from the poorly written textbook.
I would only recommend this course if it was required.
I would because I think the math is interesting, but if you take it with Hui, you are going to need to teach yourself most of it and put in a lot of work on your own time.
If you gotta, you gotta
No. Take it with Beth Anne. Don't be like me.

If you don't have to take this class, don't take it -- unless you love math and you would be fine teaching most of the material to yourself. Hui tries to teach the material in a way that was confusing (at least for me) where she spent a majority of the class deriving things and not really showing examples of how to solve a certain type of problem.
No. Only if you need it as a prerequisite for a particular major.

I was surprised by how interesting I found diff eqs to be! As long as you have the steps clearly explained to you, its only a matter of implementing them into the more complex problems. But without that concrete understanding, you can get stuck very quickly. I would recommend this class to any student but not with professor Cao. Cao did not provide that aforementioned clarity thats SO imperative to understanding diff 
eqs well. If you have the option to take it a different semester, do so. But if not, make sure you seek out the resources needed to understand the methodology of Laplace theorem, separation of variables, etc. Nick Bender was a phenomenal TF and a great example of how an instructor can really change the way you understand things. But outside of him, I had to rely heavily on outside online resources because prof Caos lectures were just not clear enough. Overall, very interesting subject but I recommend you take this course with any other professor.
HELL no. Awful class. You will only take it because you need to, but avoid Hui at all costs.
No, unless it's required by your major.
Differential Equations is very important to learn. Very cool subject. The professor is not very good at teaching the material but posts notes.
If it is taught differently, yes.
If the student wants to understand the math, and why the math is useful, then no.

I would never recommend this course to anyone if Hui is teaching it. If another professor is, go for it! I LOVED the actual math even though the course was taught so poorly. If you are ready to put in hours of work outside of class to teach yourself everything, then take this course. That's what I had to do and I was actually very successful. But if you are looking to be inspired in math, to enjoy lecture, and for something that is bearable, do not take this course. It will make you hate math unless you put in a ton of time and energy on your own.
Absolutely never. If you need to take this course for a major requirement, as I did, I do not envy you.
I wouldn't take this class if it were not required
I would, if they might use diffeq for their work in science, math or engineering.

I would recommend this course to other engineering students. I thought that the exams were very fair and despite the professor not being the best, there were enough resources to learn the material and do well.

No, I would definitely not recommend this course, but unfortunately, for many engineering majors, you have to take it. The ENAS math courses are supposed to be better than the regular MATH courses because they're more applied and therefore more interesting to engineering majors generally, but this course was just one of the worst I've taken at Yale. All the learning had to come from myself and the TAs, and even then, the final was just too hard and worth too much of our grade to do well. I have no idea if I know differential equations coming out this side of the course.
Unless something changes with the grading and lectures, no.
It's a prerequisite for most engineering majors, so most people have to take it. I had to learn the majority of the material outside of class, as lecture was not the most productive.
Unless you need it for a major, there's no reason to take it.
No, not unless they have to take it. It was interesting enough but so hard to learn and essentially we had to teach ourselves or have the TAs teach us.
absolutely not; or at least not with Hui

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they have to take it for their major. It was poorly taught and very hard to learn things in lecture. You either had to learn it from the textbook, watch a video online, or go to TA office hours.
I think it was a great course to learn dif eq
I wouldn't recommend this course unless it is a requirement or you want to extend your knowledge in math.

I would recommend the course, but not necessarily the instructor, to another student if they want to learn the basics of ordinary and partial differential equations. Note that the course does go rather fast.
